Partizánske (Slovak pronunciation: [ˈpaɾ: Partizánske is a relatively young town. Its history starts in 1938–1939
meaning approximately partisan town: when Jan Antonín Baťa of Zlín and his powerful network of companies built a shoe factory in the cadastral area of Šimonovany municipality. The newly created settlement for workers carried the name of Baťovany and was part of Šimonovany. With the growth of the factory
formerly: Baťovany: so grew the settlement. The whole municipality was renamed to Baťovany in 1948 and given town status. As a sign of recognition of local inhabitants fighting in the Slovak National Uprising
Hungarian: Simony) is a town in Trenčín: the town was renamed Partizánske on 9 February 1949.
